name: Restorative Yoga
summary: A gentle, deeply relaxing yoga practice using props to support the body in passive postures, promoting rest, recovery, and regulation of the nervous system.
description: Restorative yoga is a therapeutic style of yoga that emphasizes relaxation, gentle stretching, and mindful presence. Unlike active yoga practices, restorative yoga uses props (bolsters, blankets, blocks) to fully support the body in restful postures, often held for 5–20 minutes. The goal is not muscular effort but conscious relaxation, facilitating parasympathetic nervous system activation, stress reduction, improved sleep, and emotional balance. Widely used in integrative health, stress management, trauma recovery, and chronic illness, restorative yoga provides accessible, non-invasive support for physical and mental well-being.

practice_styles: Yoga nidra integrated with restorative practice
treatment_variants: Therapeutic yoga tailored to medical conditions
treatment_duration: Short-term: 1–2 sessions per week for 6–8 weeks
Ongoing: regular weekly or biweekly practice for maintenance
metadata.training_required: Certified yoga teacher (200-hour minimum), with additional training in restorative or therapeutic yoga
metadata.regulatory_status: Unregulated wellness practice; some integration in hospital wellness and supportive care programs

contraindications: Relative: acute musculoskeletal injuries requiring modification, severe mobility limitations without adaptations
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Very safe, gentle, and adaptable. Risks are minimal and usually related to inappropriate positioning or lack of support with props.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate for stress, anxiety, and sleep; emerging evidence for supportive care in chronic illness and cancer.

sections.text: Restorative yoga promotes parasympathetic activation through supported, passive postures and mindful breathing. Physiologically, it reduces heart rate, blood pressure, and cortisol, while enhancing vagal tone and improving heart rate variability. Psychologically, it facilitates emotional regulation, mindfulness, and trauma-informed safety. The supportive use of props allows the body to fully relax, encouraging healing and nervous system balance.

sections.preparation: Quiet environment, supportive props (bolsters, blankets, blocks), and loose comfortable clothing.
procedure: Begin with centering and mindful breathing.
Enter supported postures (e.g., supported child’s pose, reclining bound angle, legs up the wall).
Hold each posture 5–20 minutes with minimal effort.
End with guided relaxation or meditation.
sections.frequency: 1–2 times per week recommended; more frequent home practice encouraged.
sections.duration: 6–8 weeks initial course, with ongoing practice for maintenance.
sections.total_treatment_time: Sessions last 45–90 minutes; long-term practice benefits accumulate.
